children: Quality improvement (QI) refers to a systematic approach to analyzing practice performance with the aim of providing optimal evidence-based care in a reproducible and reliable manner while also improving patient safety. QI also aims to improve the health care process by reducing waste and unnecessary treatments while ensuring that all patients receive equitable care regardless of race, ethnicity, or socioeconomic background. The focus on practice performance data can be at the patient level (such as screening), the system level (such as hospital readmission rates), or the population level (such as regional mortality rates). The process of QI is ideally continuous, occurring in real time with rapid-cycle improvements and iterative change made by ongoing observations. Successful QI requires participation from all health care team members as well as patients.

title.__html: Patient Safety and Quality Issues at the Clinician Level

children: Patient Safety and Quality Issues at the Clinician Level

Physicians have the potential to both recognize and mitigate threats to patient safety. In addition, substantial variability in physician-delivered care and nonadherence to evidence-based guidelines may contribute to lack of quality care. Accordingly, QI interventions that are developed with physician input are much more likely to succeed than those developed without such consultation. Physicians also have the opportunity to improve patient safety in everyday clinical work by focusing on common domains of error, such as medications and transitions of care. Despite this, physicians participate in less than 35% of QI interventions. Common reasons for physicians not participating include lack of skills, inadequate time, financial disincentives, and perceived threats to autonomy.

Medication errors, defined as preventable inappropriate medication use, are the most common type of medical error. They are estimated to occur at a rate of 5 errors per 100 medication administrations. Medication errors can occur at any stage (prescribing/transcribing, dispensing, administering/taking, or monitoring) and by any person in the process (clinician, pharmacist, nurse, or patient). Errors may be those of omission, such as a physician not prescribing an indicated medication, or commission, such as prescribing an incorrect medication or dose.
Physicians form the first line of defense in preventing medication errors

. In prescribing medications, physicians need to review a patient's complete medical record, including medical history; medication list, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal remedies, and supplements; allergies; and laboratory data (such as renal and hepatic function) that may affect medication dosing. Physicians must also be diligent in screening for possible medication interactions.

Medication adherence, defined as the degree to which a patient adheres to the dose and interval of their prescribed pharmacologic regimen, is poor among patients with chronic medical conditions. Nonadherence, typically defined as failure to take at least 80% of a prescribed medication regimen, has been associated with increased health care utilization, poor outcomes, and increased costs. An estimated 20% to 30% of prescriptions are never filled, and an estimated 50% of patients with chronic medical conditions are nonadherent with their prescribed regimen. Medication adherence is a complex behavior that is influenced by the patient, system, and provider. The factors most strongly associated with medication adherence include strong provider-patient relationships and a patient's understanding of their medical conditions.

Patient-related and societal factors that may have a significant impact on medication adherence include a high burden of disease with complex medication regimens; financial stressors; distrust of clinicians and health care institutions; and lack of social support, including transportation. Individual physicians can have a meaningful, positive impact on medication adherence. Physicians should inquire at each visit about medication adherence in a nonjudgmental manner and avoid negative comments if nonadherence is uncovered. Patient self-report may overestimate adherence by 200%, and physicians should attempt to clearly quantify the degree of adherence. Patients should be encouraged to bring their medications to appointments, and providers should discuss the purpose of each medication. When possible, family members should be engaged. For some patients, a visiting nurse may be needed to complete home visits to further assess reasons for nonadherence and promote adherence.

There are a variety of methods to increase adherence and multimodal approaches are more likely to be successful. Physicians can promote medication adherence through pharmacotherapy regimen simplification, consultation with a clinical pharmacist, and optimization of cost incentives. Simplifying a medication regimen (such as prescribing combination pills or implementing a schedule to take pills simultaneously) is a feasible method for patients and may result in a patient taking fewer pills. However, it may require clinician time for making changes and combination pills may be more expensive. Consultation with a clinical pharmacist is a team-based approach that facilitates disease co-management, allowing physicians to utilize their time performing other tasks. This method may be costly and may not be available at all institutions. Utilizing cost incentives (such as selecting medications with lowest copays or available discounts) can be time intensive and may require clinicians to maintain knowledge of shifting copays among a large number of health insurance companies.

Patient education (online resources, handouts) is low-cost and widely available and usually requires the patient to make a time investment to become educated. Cognitive behavioral therapy in the form of self-management strategies and motivational interviewing to promote adherence can be used; when performed by a psychologist, clinicians can share responsibility of patient management. However, cognitive behavioral therapy may not be available for all patients, requires a patient's time investment, and has associated costs for use of a specialist. Patient reminders, such as text or voice alerts, can be programmed into smart phones or other technological devices, but not all patients may have access to technology and personal and interactive reminders may be more effective. Pill boxes may also be used.

When patients transition care between providers or care environments, they are at increased risk for harm. Handoffs between clinicians and teams are integral to this process and are defined as the transfer and acceptance of responsibility of patient care between clinicians through effective communication. Factors that contribute to suboptimal transitions include poor communication between health care team members, incomplete transfer of information, and inadequate patient education. Patient factors that increase likelihood of suboptimal transition of care include older age, multiple medical comorbidities, poor health literacy, language barriers, and cognitive impairment.

Excellent communication among health care team members and between providers and patients is the key to successful transition of care. The most widely used method for handoff communication is the SBAR (Situation, Background, Assessment, and Recommendation) technique (see

. Transitions are also enhanced by physician involvement in a multidisciplinary team utilizing a continuous, case-based multidisciplinary team management approach. During transitions, physicians should strive to provide clear, concise, and accurate patient records to subsequent providers. Accurate medication reconciliation, although time-consuming, is paramount because errors frequently occur; several studies have shown medication reconciliation is best performed by a pharmacist. Upon hospital discharge, physicians must focus on follow-up plans, including educating patients on the expected course and red flag symptoms that necessitate reevaluation.

To prevent medication errors, physicians must review a patient's complete medical record, including medical history; medication list, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal remedies, and supplements; allergies; and laboratory data that may affect medication dosing.
The most widely used method for handoff communication during transition of care is the SBAR (Situation, Background, Assessment, and Recommendation) technique.

title.__html: Patient Safety and Quality Issues at the Systems Level

children: Patient Safety and Quality Issues at the Systems Level

There are multiple QI models that provide structure for implementing QI interventions on a systems level. The American College of Physicians (ACP) Advance curriculum provides a useful tool set and additional resources for implementing QI interventions (
). The Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle is a frequently used method in each of the models described in this section and provides structure for continuous changes.

The Model for Improvement is the most commonly used QI model in health care. It provides a simple framework for QI interventions that relies on rapid PDSA cycles. A key underlying theme is that although not every change leads to improvement, improvement cannot occur without change. This model works best when frontline health care staff members are active participants. Users of this model begin by developing a goal by asking, “What are we trying to accomplish?” Next, to determine how to track success, users must answer, “How will we measure if a change yields an improvement?” The final step in this model is to determine what change is going to be made by asking the question, “What change can we make that will result in improvement?” Because this QI model does not help to identify causes of health care problems, it works best for problems with easily identifiable causes and evidence-based solutions. For example, a medical center may set the specific goal of increasing adherence to stroke treatment guidelines and use PDSA cycles to rapidly implement and assess the impact of changes, such as using a computerized admission order set.

The Lean model focuses on improving health care processes through two principles: waste elimination and respect for individuals. In this model, activities are classified as being either value added (directly contributing to meeting patient needs) or non–value added (requiring resources of time and space but not meeting patient needs). On average, most processes are only 5% value added and 95% non–value added. The Lean model is best applied to directly observed problems and when flow, efficiency, and speed are prioritized; involvement of frontline health care staff members is crucial because they are in the best position to identify problems. Value stream mapping is an example of the Lean model in which the steps of a process and time required for each step are graphically displayed, thereby highlighting process inefficiencies and allowing for their improvement. Using the Lean model, results can typically be seen within weeks.

Six Sigma, which refers to six standard deviations from the mean, focuses on improvement through reducing variability in patient care. It relies on understanding and controlling processes by using quantitative tools, such as analysis of variance, control charts, and mathematic modeling. Six Sigma is a five-phase process: Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control (DMAIC). In the Define phase, key measures for determining success are established. In the Measure phase, past performance levels are determined to provide a baseline to measure future improvement. In the Analyze phase, causes of the current problems and improvement opportunities are identified. Finally, in the Control phase, improvement is standardized to maintain sustainability. Six Sigma typically requires a time commitment of at least several months and substantial institutional resources to implement effectively. As such, it is best applied to complex, multistep health care problems in which an immediate cause or solution cannot be readily identified, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections.

Operational Excellence is a continuous QI model that has its roots in industry and frequently uses aspects of Lean, Six Sigma, and other QI models. It is a management system that aims for consistent and reliable operation of an institutional strategy by focusing on leadership, problem solving, and teamwork. The main focus is on patient needs, but it also aims to empower and engage all staff members. All levels of an organization must be invested in the model for it to be successful. Staff members must be empowered to identify problems and bring these problems, as well as potential solutions, to the attention of others and leadership. Leadership must value the opinions and contributions of the frontline staff and promote a no-blame culture in which there is no fear of reprisal. PDSA cycles, often centered on the ideas of frontline workers, are commonly used as a structural approach within the Operational Excellence framework to promote change. Operational Excellence can be used to improve quality by focusing on key performance indicators of quality and safety, such as timely completion of medication reconciliation.
The Model for Improvement, Lean, Six Sigma, and Operational Excellence are examples of quality improvement models that can be used in the health care setting.

Multiple organizations and payers assess quality of care as a condition of accreditation or participation. For example, the Joint Commission assesses a wide variety of quality metrics, such as timely provision of reperfusion therapy in acute myocardial infarction, the incidence of potentially preventable venous thromboembolic disease, and rates of influenza immunization.

Medicare also has a significant impact on measurement of health care quality. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services assess areas of hospital performance, such as hospital mortality and readmission rates, and areas of ambulatory care performance, such as hypertension control, prevention of diabetic nephropathy, and colorectal cancer screening. Patients are surveyed regarding the quality of their experience after hospitalization via the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Provider and Systems Survey. title.__html: Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Initiatives

children: Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Initiatives

The patient-centered medical home is a model of providing primary health care that is coordinated by a team of clinicians, including physicians, advanced practice practitioners, nurses, pharmacists, physical therapists, patient educators, and case managers, housed within a collaborative group practice. The functions of the patient-centered medical home include providing comprehensive health care, coordinating care across settings, improving access to services with extended clinician availability, and engaging in quality and safety improvement programs. Further information about the patient-centered medical home is available from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) (

The concept of the patient-centered medical home has been expanded in the patient-centered medical neighborhood; this includes other clinicians and institutions (such as specialists and hospitals) involved in an individual patient's care.

The ACP High Value Care initiative aims to improve health, avoid harms, and eliminate wasteful practices. This initiative addresses high-value care broadly, offering learning resources for clinicians and medical educators, clinical guidelines, best practice advice, and patient resources on a wide variety of related topics (

). Components of the High Value Care initiative that are evident in MKSAP 19 include the identification of High Value Care key points in the text and a list of high-value care recommendations assembled for each MKSAP section.
The Choosing Wisely initiative was developed by the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation in collaboration with

to encourage discussions between clinicians and patients on selecting tests, treatments, and procedures that are evidence-based and truly necessary, thereby avoiding unnecessary care. More than 80 specialist organizations have participated to create lists of overused tests and treatments in their specialties (
has generated patient education materials based on these lists to engage and empower patients to participate in care discussions.

The Joint Commission establishes annual National Patient Safety Goals to address important issues in health care safety. Recommended by a panel of patient safety experts and applied to a variety of patient care settings, the National Patient Safety Goals center on interventions that have the highest impact on quality and safety. In publishing the goals, the Joint Commission also provides specific metrics for each goal to facilitate implementation. Goals are customized to the care setting and separate goals are provided for hospitals, ambulatory health centers, and nursing care centers, among others. title.__html: Health Information Technology and Patient Safety

children: Health Information Technology and Patient Safety

Health information technology (HIT) is the use of an electronic environment to share patient health information and facilitate patient management. The electronic health record (EHR), computerized physician order entry (CPOE), and computerized clinical decision support (CDS) are some common examples of HIT.

The EHR is a compilation of all health data for a specific patient, including medical notes and test results, in a digital format. The EHR enables the timely sharing of patient information by multiple users, resulting in improved communication and care efficiency.
CPOE is a system by which clinicians electronically enter medication, radiology, and laboratory orders, thereby eliminating errors and delays related to illegible handwriting.

CDS is the use of information technology to facilitate clinical decision making. When integrated into a CPOE system, CDS can highlight potential contraindications to diagnostic tests, specify dose recommendations, identify potential drug interactions, and suggest modifications to drug dosages in patients with kidney or liver dysfunction. CDS within the EHR can also promote protocols to improve care and provide ready access to clinical guidelines.

Limitations of HIT include the expense associated with system implementation and maintenance as well as concerns related to protection of patient privacy. Although useful for preventing many types of errors, HIT does not provide a fail-safe against errors and may facilitate errors itself, such as those resulting from charting templates and use of the copy-and-paste function in composing notes. Alert fatigue, wherein clinicians are subjected to so many alerts they begin to ignore all of them, is a substantial drawback to CDS and can decrease the effectiveness of alert systems.
Useful resources for incorporation of HIT in practice are available from ACP (

As defined by AHRQ, health literacy is the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand the information required to make informed health decisions. Low health literacy is more common among older adults, minority populations, persons with lower socioeconomic status, and medically underserved groups. Low health literacy may hinder patients' ability to describe their health concerns, complete health forms accurately, understand medical information, and manage their health conditions. Furthermore, evidence shows that low health literacy is associated with poorer health outcomes and decreased utilization of care.
Clinicians need to be aware of the health literacy of their patients and identify those who may need assistance. Tools to assess health literacy in specific populations are available from AHRQ (

) and include the Short Assessment of Health Literacy and the Rapid Estimate of Adult Literacy in Medicine. Another instrument available for use is the Newest Vital Sign, which can help predict a patient's ability to comprehend common instructions related to frequent primary care scenarios. This tool and multiple other health literacy measures are available through the Health Literacy Tool Shed (

Clinicians can improve patient understanding by using simple sentences, repeating information, providing an opportunity for the patient to ask questions, and supplying the patient with educational materials written in plain language. The teach-back method, wherein the clinician asks the patient to describe his or her understanding of the situation in his or her own words, can further assess a patient's command of the situation and provide valuable insight into patient knowledge and health literacy.
